awd_titl_txt: The Accuracy of Eyewitness Identification in Lineups
awd_abstract_narration:
In criminal justice it is critical to identify guilty suspects accurately and avoid mistaken identification of innocent suspects. Consequently, best practices for constructing lineups provide that suspects should not stand out from other lineup members. Yet, data has established that criminal suspects with facial features matching an African phenotype are more likely to be chosen from a lineup than those with less Black or African features. This puts innocent suspects with African facial features at risk of misidentification, especially if lineups are constructed with suspects having more African facial features than other lineup members. This project examines whether certain facial features influence mistaken identification of innocent suspects and correct identifications of guilty ones. It thus will provide information designed to improve the accuracy of eyewitness identification, as well as guidance to judges, attorneys, and jurors when evaluating the identification of phenotypically African suspects.

This project will involve a series of studies that examine how phenotypic facial features affect the accuracy of eyewitness identification. First, this project will test whether phenotypic bias (the tendency to view people with African features as criminal) in eyewitness identification is due to stereotype influence during the encoding of witnessed events, failures to use deliberative processes to correct for stereotype influence on judgments, or a combination of the two. This study also will test assumptions behind applied lineup theory, which suggests that automatic recognition processes lead to accurate identifications and deliberate processes introduce bias. These outcomes are in opposition to dual-process theories of stereotyping, which predict that phenotypic bias would influence judgments automatically and that deliberate processes would be required to correct for the biasing effects of stereotypes. Further studies in this project explore the interaction of phenotypic bias with factors that bias witnesses toward mistaken identifications. De-identified data from the project will be made publicly available. As a result, this project will test multiple theoretic foundations on lineups, as well as the potential mechanisms behind phenotypic bias, which may impair the accuracy of eyewitness identification.

por.por_cntn:
Phenotypic bias is the tendency to attribute greater criminality to Black men who have facial features that more closely resemble an African phenotype (e.g., darker skin, wider nose, thicker lips, more prominent brow, textured hair) than to Black men with a more European facial phenotypic expression (e.g., lighter skin, narrower nose, thinner lips, less textured hair). The PI conducted a series of four studies to examine whether phenotypic bias affects both mistaken identification of innocent suspects and correct identifications of guilty ones. Study 1 tested whether phenotypic bias is caused by stereotype influence while forming a memory of witnessed events, failures to correct for stereotype influence on judgments, or a combination of the two. However, we found that participants were more likely to identify guilty Black culprits who expressed a more African phenotype than those who expressed a more European phenotype. This effect was the result of witnesses’ increased ability to tell the phenotypically African suspects apart rather from their fellow lineup members rather than an increase in witnesses making an identification when the culprit had a more African phenotype. This pattern of effects is not the result of a general phenotypic bias, which would have shown itself as a general increase in making an identification of a suspect with a more African (rather than opposed European) phenotypic expression. In Study 2, Black participants (22%) identified the Black suspect sat a greater rate than did White participants (13%). Again, we found no evidence of phenotypic bias, which would have manifested as participants identifying suspects with a more African phenotypic expression more often than they identified suspects with a less African/more European phenotypic expression. In Studies 3 and 4, witnesses were more likely to identify suspects, irrespective of their guilt or their racial phenotype, who were surrounded by fillers who did not match the suspect's phenotype than by fillers who did match the suspect's phenotype. These effects obtained irrespective of whether the lineup was conducted using best practices for conducting lineups. Again, there was no evidence that having an African phenotype put Black suspects at greater risk of misidentification. 

The intellectual merit of this project is that it explored whether the phenotypic bias that has been demonstrated in jury verdicts, criminal sentencing, and police officer decisions to shoot extend to the eyewitness context. The findings from this project suggest that it does not. There was no evidence, across four studies, that having an African phenotype, in and of itself, put suspects at greater risk of misidentification despite robust evidence that this phenotype creates other risks in the criminal legal system. Instead, the studies demonstrated the importance of choosing fillers (i.e., lineup members who are known to be innocent of the crime) that match the racial phenotype of the suspect to reduce the risk of identification errors.

This project also made several contributions to the National Science Foundation’s category of the broader impacts.  The project has provided professional development for four doctoral students (three women), including the development of stimulus materials, programming of computer software to present the experimental stimuli to participants, collecting and analyzing data, and managing the activities of a number of master's and undergraduate students who worked on the project. These projects also provided training opportunities for 39 undergraduate and master's research assistants (RAs), of which 1/3 were BIPOC students. In assisting with this project, RAs have gained experience developing research materials, testing research paradigms, collecting data from in-person participants, managing research teams, managing and analyzing data, and preparing manuscripts for submission. To date, nine (~25%) research assistants have matriculated into doctoral programs and four have entered MA programs. Thus, the proposed activity gave opportunities for students, some from underrepresented groups, to participate in an integration of teaching, training, learning, and research. Second, results of this research have been presented at multiple conferences, one manuscript has been published in an open access journal—so it is freely available to all, and other manuscripts are in preparation or under review. Finally, the findings from this research suggest that the police must take specific care when constructing lineups with Black suspects to match the facial phenotype of the suspect, otherwise the suspect will stand out, which increases the risk of misidentification of innocent suspects.
